text.0: sing forth to him whom many men invoke to him whom many laud.
text.1: invite the powerful indra with your songs of praise.
text.2: whose lofty mightfor doubly strong is hesupports the heavens and earth.
text.3: and hills and plains and floods and light with manly power.
text.4: such praised by many thou art king alone thou smitest vṛtras dead.
text.5: to gain o indra spoils of war and high renown.
text.6: we sing this strong and wild delight of thine which conquers in the fray.
text.7: which caster of the stone gives room and shines like gold.
text.8: wherewith thou also foundest lights for Āyu and for manus sake.
text.9: now joying in this sacred grass thou beamest forth.
text.10: this day too singers of the hymn praise as of old this might of thine.
text.11: win thou the waters day by day thralls of the strong.
text.12: that lofty indrapower of thine thy strength and thine intelligence.
text.13: thy thunderbolt for which we long the wish makes keen.
text.14: o indra heaven and earth augment thy manly power and thy renown.
text.15: the waters and thy mountains stir and urge thee on.
text.16: viṣṇu the lofty ruling power varuṇa mitra sing thy praise.
text.17: in thee the marut3 company have great delight.
text.18: o indra thou wast born the lord of men most liberal of thy gifts.
text.19: excellent deeds for evermore are all thine own.
text.20: ever alone o highlypraised thou sendest vṛtras to their rest.
text.21: none else than indra executes the mighty deed.
text.22: though here and there in varied hymns indra men call on thee for aid.
text.23: still with our heroes fight and win the light of heaven.
text.24: already have all forms of him entered our spacious dwellingplace.
text.25: for victory stir thou indra up the lord of might.
